comments:
Recreate steps:
1. Open Preferences>Java>Installed JREs
2. Click Add button
3. Select a installed JRE with Simplified Chinese folder name, then Click OK.
4. you could see the JRE had been added into the list box.
5. click OK button
6. reopen the Preferences, the new added JRE was disappear

Created an attachment (id=36640)
select Simplified folder JRE

Created an attachment (id=36641)
The JRE with Chinese Folder had added to the listbox.

Created an attachment (id=36642)
Reopen the Preference, the new added JRE was disappeared.

Moving to JDT/Debug.
Would you have any stack trace in your .log file in the .metadata folder?

I believe this is similar to bug 32206, which is a VM limitation. We use a Runtime.exec to infer default libraries. It looks like command lines with DB chars do not always work via java.lang.Runtime.exec(...). 

Propose to mark as dup.

Karice, do you have a machine where you can test this? I think this is the same problem as running/debugging a project containing DB chars - we use Runtime.exec(...) to launch an OS process, and this does not seem to work.
Hmm, i have a chinese xp machine, but not a chinese win2003 server machine.  Will that suffice?
I think XP should be similar enough.

Turns out you can use an english machine to replicate.  If you create a folder with chinese, japanese, or hebrew characters that contains a jdk, that entry will not be retained in the installed jre's preferences page.

Darin, I see that Runtime.exec() is called when adding a JRE, but perhaps if this operation is going to fail then the new JRE shouldn't be added to the list and perhaps an error message should be shown.

Darin, seems to me this one should be resolved as a dup of 32206.  Do you agree?  I would like for this bug to be resolved (one way or another) asap since this one is on IES's list of serious defects.

Looks like this is not a dup of bug 32206.

JREs are stored as a user preference. The preference value is a string encoded in UTF8 format. It looks like the preference store encodes the string using the "8859_1" character set (via java.util.Properties). 

DJ, is the launching plug-in using an old/incorrect preference store?

(MORE)

So, when the preference is set, and later decoded back into a set of JREs, the Chinses characters show up as ??? and the JRE is tossed, since the location of the the JRE does not exist.

We store the preferences in java.util.Properties files which don't handle DB chars. Strings with DB chars need to be unicode escaped in Properties files.

For 3.2 users of the Prefs API (e.g. debug) can encode potentially problematic strings before putting them in the preference store.

For 3.3 we need to have something at the Platform level to handle this.

I will provide the encode/decode algorithm for 3.2.

After re-reading the javadoc for java.util.Properties and then using common sense (hey, we have translations for languages that contain DB chars so how do they work?) we realized that its not a deficiency in the Properties object but something else is going on.

We have verified that when the vm's file path is stored in the preference file, it indeed has the offending characters unicode escaped.

Here is a stack trace from when I try and install a new JRE which lives in a directory that has DB chars in it. It looks like there is a problem running the library detector code in the external jar.

!ENTRY org.eclipse.jdt.launching 4 4 2006-04-19 11:55:10.344
!MESSAGE Failed to retrieve default libraries for D:\?\jdk1.5.0_06

For me, library detection works. I see the libs appear in the "libraries" list. For me, the problem seems to be persisting/restoring the preference with the DB chars.

As well, I tried creating a VM with a Chinese name, and an English file system location. The caused the name to appear properly when closing the "Add VM" dialog, but when the preference dialog was closed/re-opened, the VM re-appeared with a name of "???". The preference file in the OS is stored with escaped DB chars, but seems to return ??? for the DB chars when a preference is retrieved from the store.

??? usually indicates that the font being used to display these glyphs doesn't have the matching characters. I assume you are using the default (Tahoma) font - try an east asian default and see what happens.
Don't think that its a font problem...when I breakpoint the #save method the debugger shows the correct DB chars in the Variables view...

Created an attachment (id=39030)
test plug-in

ok, just to prove I'm not crazy I created a test plug-in. 

- In your workbench click on the sample icon and it will open a directory chooser. 
- Select a dir with db chars in a segment and hit OK. 
- It will display a dialog with the full path. 
- When you hit OK it will save that value to a properties file.
- Then it loads it and displays the result in another dialog.

One thing to note is that the preference value that debug is storing is really an xml string. There might be something weird happening to it when its being parsed? I will try and investigate this further later today.
Found that we parse the string, but we don't decode to bytes as UTF8. Too bad, DJ's not going crazy... just a bug in debug.
Don't jump to conclusions...just because you have a bug in debug does not mean that DJ is not going crazy :-)
Hmm...I would ask for votes on this but I'm afraid I would come out on the losing end of it. :-)

Crazy or not... I fixed up the code to properly restore the preference using UTF8. This allows the JRE to be detected/saved with a Chinese name/location. However, when the location has Chinese characters, we fail to detect libraries properly and cannot launch programs with the VM for the same reason as bug 32206. So, the fix is in, but the end result is that you cannot use the VM.

These errors appear when detecting the real library info for the JRE. When it fails, we assign it a set of "default" libs, but still cannot launch the VM.

Please verify, Kevin.

verified
